when I'm running any kind of Workshop about DDD or figuring out how businesses and domains work one of the simplest and
most effective things you can do is just be concrete and be specific so a very simple example is if you're
modeling some workflow you might have customer signed up customer placed an
order customer specify the shipping customer receive that order
from a high level that makes sense and you might feel like ah we we get this pretty simple pretty simple
business rules four steps in the process customer gets their products that's Implement that but when you stop being
specific that's when you start to uncover the real rules and complexity so in a
situation like that we might ask questions like what can be different about a customer their age their location
um their profession how might these different ways of segmenting customers affect how the process is carried out it
might be oh yeah if we have an older person they get a discount if someone's worked in the armed forces they get a discount we can then apply that same
logic to the order what kind of orders can people place large order small order food order perishable order that's what
I mean by being specific so whenever whenever you're in a session and you're mapping out businesses and domains
I would say be specific try and be as specific as possible I was in a workshop last year with a company in Germany all

why is this happening every Sprint why is the team having a bad reputation turns out when the team starts
implementing these features in code they're like oh that's more complex than we thought we've got more edge cases
here we've got business rules that weren't explained properly so when the team's trying to implement the code they're still trying to figure out the
requirements and then the business aren't happy about that because they don't get much done so we introduced example mapping
example mapping is a technique there are different ways you can do this you can apply it with other techniques like
event storming but effectively you take a requirement and you try and break it down into into various scenarios
the key thing is the way you do this so the way we did this and the way I recommend doing this is if you're
working in Sprints let's say or you're working in two week iterations then
let's say you're in iteration a and you're going to be working in iteration B next nothing too complex there when
you're in iteration B you'll do example mapping for the features you're going to work on in iteration B
you're only looking ahead two weeks it's not anything waterfall nothing like that but what we discovered by doing this is
that when the developers found all of these extra edge cases we could go back to the business and say
you gave us these requirements we've mapped it out into all these Feats examples it's a bit more complex than
you thought and we gave them a choice would you like us to implement more features and it will take more time or
would you like to take away some of these edge cases and we'll ignore them so all that Discovery the team was doing
drawing implementation they were now doing that up front which was meaning less blockers and getting work done in
the Sprints even more importantly I would say is that with example mapping the teams
getting into the habit of thinking in these concrete scenarios they're learning more about the domain and so even if you can't do things like event
storming which take a lot of effort take a lot of time get people together spending a day two days
example mapping is is one of those things that I would say
